1: cultivate an appreciation of beauty: Essentially the child's role is to be energetic when required. You can allow your child to cultivate an appreciation of beauty through sight and hearing. For example, try enjoying different cuisine, being with nature, or even appreciating aesthetic creations like buildings and paintings.
2: try to resist too much sexual activit: Try to resist too much sexual activity so that your body can replenish your cerebrospinal fluid, one of the most energetic substances in the body and benefits your cognitive abilities.
3: wake up in the morning with a specifi: Wake up in the morning with a specific goal to look forward to. Every night, you review the next day and choose a particular task that should be relatively interesting and exciting. The next morning, open your eyes and visualise the chosen event to be excited.
1: meditation: Essentially the adult's role is to be calm when required. Try meditation. You can start by listening to a guided meditation podcast and do it consistently in your schedule.
2: do something relaxing: Do something relaxing outside your creative domain or job within a short timeframe, like having a 20-minute nap or listening to music after lunch. Giving yourself a short period of rest will effectively charge your battery.Listening to calming music or podcasts. It is better to combine it with some slow-paced exercise such as yoga.
1: do not assume you know everything: When discussing your creative domain with your colleague, do not assume you know everything and feel mentally superior; be open and curious about what others think and do.
2: stop being judgemental: Stop being judgemental and try not to make assumptions. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, be open to listening and accepting the opinion of others and never take part in gossip
3: do not take appreciation so seriously: Do not take appreciation so seriously. When receiving a compliment, try not to let it inflate your ego, acknowledge the remark with a simple thank you and carry on with the conversation.
1: time slot to read materials: Plan a time slot to read materials corresponding to your creative domain daily. Reading stimulates every part of your brain and requires multiple cognitive functions such as memory, abstract reasoning, comprehension, and attention
2: continuing education: Aim to be a student for life. Continuing education could enhance your smartness. Try activities like listening to a podcast, watching TED talks that are related to your creative domain.
3: do brain training: Do brain training. Go to a puzzle store and pick up a puzzle you like and start solving them. There is also some free brain training app available on the market where you could try to stimulate your brain.
1: surprise at least one person: Try to surprise at least one person with your playful mind. Creating an element of surprise is a great way to exhibit one’s playfulness.
2: experiment with your appearance: Experiment with your appearance and try to look different. Dress yourself up and play with your appearance.
3: anthropomorphizing exercise: Try anthropomorphizing exercise. Practice naming inanimate objects, giving them human qualities and characteristics would flourish your ability to play.
1: take charge of your schedule: Take charge of your schedule. Plan your day before, allocate sufficient time for your creative domain and use your time efficiently.
2: remind yourself why you want to be di: Remind yourself why you want to be disciplined. Write down why you want to focus discipline on your objective on a sticky note and put it in a few places like next to your bed, by your computer, or your bathroom mirror.
3: embrace the discomfort: Embrace the discomfort: take a cold shower, take the stairs instead of elevators, read a book instead of watching TV, walk or bike instead of driving, and when possible, try to be vegetarian for a day if you are a meat lover.
1: draw a picture of your dream world: Try imagining a place. We call it the magic, mystical mountain where anything is possible. You can have powers, and magical beings exist in this world. Practice drawing a picture of your dream world.
2: turn the screen off and reading the b: Instead of watching a series on TV, try turning the screen off and reading the book. After several weeks, you should witness your imagination being unleashed, and you could also depict the world in that story.
3: loose part play: Try loose part play. Find upcycled or recycled material and repurpose them into endless open-ended creative construction projects.Launch a play with your creations from an idea or book related to your creative domain.
1: delay gratification: We can control our impulses. Try to delay gratification of a desire until it can be appropriately met. For example, if you are a coffee addict, you can reward yourself with a coffee after completing a task instead of drinking it while doing the job.
2: assess before making decision: Try to assess and weigh the benefit and loss of a decision with a risk table, metric evaluation, or empirical analysis before making your decision.
3: importance of being proactive: Realise the importance of being proactive. Imagine a problem you are having, instead of focusing on what you cannot control and blaming others, try to focus on what you can control and find ways to solve the problem.
2: calling instead of texting: Try calling instead of texting whenever possible. You can start by looking at a friend you recently texted and calling them by phone.
3: hang out with close friend: Invite your close friends to hang out where you feel comfortable talking and initiate the small talk by asking how you are doing recently and sharing yours too.
2: pursue a solitary hobby: Pursue a solitary hobby such as gardening, reading and writing, painting, playing golf, playing an instrument or hiking.
3: staying in on friday night: Try staying in on Friday night and create an introverted space for yourself. You can either do a solitary hobby or just enjoy and relax on your own.
1: practise mindfulness: Try practising mindfulness. Accept yourself with all your flaws and faults when something is wrong. Let go of the anxiety and guilt and fill yourself with positive thoughts on how you will face the problem next time.
2: ask for help when needed: Ask for help when needed. Do not be shy, seeking for assistance not only shows humility, but also help from others may sometimes inspire you.
3: being grateful: Try being grateful and appreciative for what you have. Stop for a while, take time to count your blessings and be thankful for what has been bestowed upon you.
1: cherished objects: Put some cherished objects you feel proud of, such as diplomas and trophies, on your work desk to shape a personalised space. Try spending a moment enjoying what you have accomplished.
2: write down all the positive things: Write down all the positive things you did, no matter how small, make it a daily practice and keep a log of it. Begin each entry with the words “I’m proud of that” and be specific and detailed. Periodically reread your pride Log.
3: surround yourself with positive peopl: Surround yourself with positive people. Take a moment and think about how your friends make you feel, cut loose on those who constantly judge you and spend more time with friends that love you and want the best for you.
1: voice out your opinion: During a discussion, voice out your opinion when it comes to your mind and do not let it slide after the discussion
2: play competitive games: Play competitive games to win. Try to involve yourself in a competition or an event where it requires you to pitch to others like debate.
3: embody your emotions: Try to find a person and have that person communicate an emotion using only their body. You have to guess what feeling they embody, and then you each take turns picking an emotion and acting it out. This game will help you become more practised in controlling your physicality and presenting confidence, even if you don’t feel it.
2: develop what you lack: Develop what you lack. Try to identify your most apparent characteristic by asking your friend for help. Then, you can begin to try the opposite and nurture it.
3: summarise a person central point: During a conversation, when a person speaks, pay attention to listen more, and summarise it in your own words back to them to see if you get their context right.
1: trust your passion: Trust your passion. When you are passionate about an activity but are unsure whether you should risk it, listen to your passion, trust it and risk your time pursuing it. List down those activities and start risking.
2: hold unpopular views: Hold unpopular views on political and social issues. When you come across a political and social issue you are against, list down the reasons and actions that can make it better.
3: take a chance on yourself: Take a chance on yourself. Write down something worth for you to risk your money or time on and pursue it spontaneously. Give yourself a chance, be brave to accept it when you make the right choice and cope with it when things go awry.
1: be religious for a day: If you have a religion, try to go to the place of worship of your religion and abide by the rules of the religion. If you do not have one, try considering and participating in the religious activity with your family
2: stick to the same bedtime: Go to bed early and rise early each day. Stick to the same bedtime and wake up at the same time every morning, even on the weekends.
3: be prudent on your finances: Be prudent on your finances. Try making a budget for your spending and stick to it. Whenever you get your paycheck, make sure to pay your bills before making any purchases.
1: improving the complexity: Practice improving the quality or complexity of a few everyday activities. This will allow you to keep enjoying the activity. You might also feel ready to tackle something more challenging such as a new interest after this activity.
2: passion breeds passion: Find out what you like and hate about life on your own by experiencing them and keep a record of what you did each day and how you felt about it. Then, start doing more of what you love, which excites you and less of what you hate.
3: significant motivators: When starting a new task in your creative domain, list down some of your significant motivators. It could be your core values or small stuff like rewarding yourself after a milestone and using those motivators to continue striving.
1: create a vision board: Create a vision board, paste images that represent your goals and personal needs, no matter how small they are, onto that board. This exercise helps you practice prioritising your wants and needs
2: make time for reflection: Make time for reflection. Include this in your schedule and review what you have accomplished and what remains to be done. Think further about them and discuss them with a trusted friend, colleague, or mentor.
3: set up a goal: When doing a task in your creative domain, set up a goal that measures what you perceive as success in that task. Be thorough and specific on the metrics and criteria of success. You can use the SMART guideline for the goal.
3: learn to express your feelings: Learn to express your feelings. Expose your emotions to someone trustworthy who could understand what you are going through. If you cannot find one, write it down in your diary and a log.
1: spend money on an experience: Spend money on an experience rather than a possession. Instead of buying a new car, try to spend it on travelling, take photos to commemorate your experience and create an album to store those memories. The experience continues to provide joy through memories.
2: involve in charity: Volunteer yourself to help others or involve in charity. You will realise that contributing to the betterment of the people will boost your spirit, giving you internal peace and happiness.
3: celebrate small wins: Celebrate small wins. When accomplishing a small objective in your creative domain, seek that as a win, take yourself to a nice dinner or buy yourself a gift to celebrate it.
